case_name: Messrs. Bundelkhand Motor Transport Company, Nowgaon v. Behari Lal Chaurasia

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 51 of 65 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 51 of 65.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated November 11, 1964 of Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 238 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated November 11, 1964 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc,. Petition No. 238 of 1964.

facts.text: Messrs. Bundelkhand Motor Transport Company, Nowgaon is the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Messrs. Bundelkhand Motor Transport Company, Nowgaon-hereinafter called the appellants permit under the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939

facts.text: In 1957 Regional Transport Authority Jabalpur granted permit to appellants to ply stage carriages on inter-regional route Jabalpur to Chhatarpur.

anchor.surface_text: In 1957 the Regional Transport Authority, Jabalpur granted to Messrs. Bundelkhand Motor Transport Company, Nowgaon-hereinafter called the appellants permit under the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939 to ply stage carriages on an inter- regional route-Jabalpur to Chhatarpur-

facts.text: Permit granted in 1957 was countersigned by Regional Transport Authority Rewa.

anchor.surface_text: in the State of Madhya Pradesh, and the permit was companyntersigned by the Regional Transport Authority, Rewa within whose jurisdiction a part of the route lay.

facts.text: Permit renewed in 1960 for three years expiring on August 9, 1963 by Regional Transport Authority Jabalpur.

anchor.surface_text: The permit was renewed in 1960 for a period of three years expiring on August 9, 1963 by the Regional Transport Authority, Jabalpur,

facts.text: Renewal in 1960 countersigned by Regional Transport Authority Rewa.

anchor.surface_text: and it was companynter signed by the Regional Transport Authority, Rewa.

facts.text: On June 7, 1963 appellant applied to Regional Transport Authority Jabalpur for renewal of permit.

anchor.surface_text: On June 7, 1963 the appellant applied to the Regional Transport Authority, Jabalpur for renewal of the permit,

facts.text: By order dated December 6, 1963 permit renewed for period ending February 9, 1966 by Regional Transport Authority Jabalpur.

anchor.surface_text: and by order dated December 6, 1963 the permit was renewed for the period ending February 9, 1966.

facts.text: On December 7, 1963 appellant requested Regional Transport Authority Rewa to countersign the renewed permit.

anchor.surface_text: By its application dated December 7, 1963 the appellant requested the Regional Transport Authority, Rewa to companyntersign the permit so renewed.

facts.text: Application to Rewa published on January 2, 1964 as required by s.57 read with s.63(3) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: This application was published as required by s. 57 read with s. 63 3  of the Act on January 2, 1964.

facts.text: Three motor transport operators including first respondent Behari Lal Chaurasia objected to countersignature on ground of limitation under s.58(2) proviso one.

anchor.surface_text: Three motor transport operators, amongst whom was the first respondent Behari Lal Chaurasia, objected to the grant of companynter-signature to the permit, inter alia, on the ground that the application was barred by the law of limitation prescribed by s. 58 2  proviso one,

facts.text: Regional Transport Authority Rewa overruled objection and granted countersignature by order dated March 17, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: and the Regional Transport Authority, Rewa had numberpower to grant companynter-signature of renewal after the expiry of that period. The Regional Transport Authority, Rewa overruled the objection, and by order dated March 17, 1964 granted companynter-signature of the permit.

facts.text: First respondent applied to High Court of Madhya Pradesh under Arts. 226 and 227 for writ quashing order dated March 17, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent then applied to the High Court of Madhya Pradesh under Arts. 226 227 of the Constitution for a writ quashing the order dated March 17, 1964 passed by the Regional Transport Authority, Rewa.

facts.text: High Court quashed order dated March 17, 1964 holding application for countersignature renewal barred by s.58(2) and Rewa lacked jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: In the view of the High Court an application for renewal of the permit and an application for renewal of companynter-signature must be made within the period prescribed by S. 58 2  of the Act, and the appellant having failed to apply within that period, the application of the appellant for renewal of the companynter-signature was barred and the Regional Transport Authority, Rewa had numberjurisdiction to companyntersign the permit renewed by the Regional Transport Authority, Jabalpur. The High Court accordingly quashed the order dated March 17, 1964.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under Art. 133(1)(c) for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: With certificate granted by the High Court under Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution, the appellant has appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Application for countersignature of renewal made to Regional Transport Authority Jabalpur and rejected.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case an application for companynter-signature of renewal of the permit was made to the Regional Transport Authority, Jabalpur, and it was rejected.

facts.text: Truth of recital that RTA Jabalpur declined countersignature renewal accepted by counsel.

anchor.surface_text: But it appears clear from the following recital in the order of the Regional Transport Authority, Rewa, that the application for companyntersignature was made to the Authority at Jabalpur and it was rejected Need for moving this authority for getting the companynter- signature renewed certainly arose when the R.T.A. Jabalpur declined to sanction the renewal of companynter-signature. Truth of this recital is accepted by companynsel at the Bar.

facts.text: Supreme Court confirms High Court order quashing countersignature but for different reasons.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore companyfirm the order of the High Court, but for different reasons.

facts.text: Permit granted/renewed by RTA Jabalpur valid only for route between Jabalpur and point of entry into Rewa region.

anchor.surface_text: We deem it, however, necessary to make it clear that our order does number affect the validity of the permit -ranted by the Regional Transport Authority, Jabalpur, insofar as it relates to the route between Jabalpur and the point of entry of the route into the Rewa region.

facts.text: Route is inter-regional: Jabalpur to Chhatarpur, part in Rewa jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: an inter- regional route-Jabalpur to Chhatarpur-in the State of Madhya Pradesh, and the permit was companyntersigned by the Regional Transport Authority, Rewa within whose jurisdiction a part of the route lay.

facts.text: First respondent is Behari Lal Chaurasia.

anchor.surface_text: amongst whom was the first respondent Behari Lal Chaurasia, objected

facts.text: Permit renewed by Jabalpur operative only up to entry into Rewa region as Jabalpur declined countersignature under rule 63.

anchor.surface_text: The Regional Transport Authority, Jabalpur renewed the permit for the Jabalpur region, but declined to companyntersign the permit in exercise of the power companyferred by r. 63 framed under s. 68 of the Motor Vehicles Act in respect of the route within the Rewa region.

facts.text: RTA Rewa order granting countersignature invalid as it overrode Jabalpur's discretion.

anchor.surface_text: In any event as one Regional Transport Authority is number companypetent to sit in judgment over the discretion exercised by any other Regional Transport Authority upon whom the power is companyferred in regard to a particular matter under the statue, the order of the Regional Transport Authority, Rewa granting companyntersignature in the teeth of the earlier order of the Jabalpur Authority was invalid.

The first respondent then applied to the High Court of Madhya Pradesh under Arts. 226 227 of the Constitution for a writ quashing the order dated March 17, 1964 passed by the Regional Transport Authority, Rewa.

The first respondent then applied to the High Court of Madhya Pradesh under Arts. 226 227 of the Constitution for a writ quashing the order dated March 17, 1964 passed by the Regional Transport Authority, Rewa.
With certificate granted by the High Court under Art. 133 1 c of the Constitution, the appellant has appealed to this Court.

anchor.surface_text: Section 45 of the Motor Vehicles Act provides that every application for a permit shall be made to the Regional Transport Authority of the region in which it is proposed to use the vehicle or vehicles. By the proviso to s. 45 it is enacted that where it is proposed to use the vehicle or vehicles in two or more regions lying within the same State,

anchor.surface_text: Section 47 sets out the procedure of the Regional Transport Authority in considering applications for stage carriage permits and prescribes the matters which may be taken into account by that officer in granting or rejecting the applications for stage carriage permits.

concepts.interpretation: Procedure and considerations for stage carriage permits.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 48 it is provided that subject to the provisions of s. 47, a Regional Transport Authority may, on an application made to it, grant a stage carriage permit, in accordance with the application or with such modifications as it deems fit, valid for a specified route or routes or specified area. Sub-section 3 of s. 48 authorises the Authority to grant a stage carriage permit subject to one or more of the conditions specified therein.

concepts.interpretation: Grant of stage carriage permit with conditions.

anchor.surface_text: Section 57 prescribes the procedure in applying for and granting permits. An application for a stage carriage permit or a public carriers permit shall, it is provided by sub-s. 2 , be made not less than six weeks before the date on which it is desired that the permit shall take effect,

concepts.interpretation: Procedure including publication not less than 6 weeks before.

anchor.surface_text: By sub-s. 1 of s. 58 it is provided that a stage carriage permit or a contract carriage permit other than a temporary permit shall be effective without renewal for such period not less than three years and not more than five years, as the Regional Transport Authority may specify in the permit. Sub-section 2 enacts that a permit may be renewed on an application made and disposed of as if it were an application for a permit,

concepts.interpretation: Renewal procedure assimilated to fresh permit; 60 days notice; can entertain late up to 15 days.

anchor.surface_text: Section 63 deals with inter-regional and inter-State permits. The material parts of the section are as under - Except as may be otherwise prescribed, a permit granted by the Regional Transport Authority of any one region shall not be valid in any other region, unless the permit has been countersigned by the Regional Transport Authority of that other region,

concepts.interpretation: Permit valid in granting region until countersigned; countersigning authority can attach conditions; Ch IV applies to countersignatures.

issues.text: Whether an application for renewal of countersignature must be made within the period prescribed by Section 58(2) of the Motor Vehicles Act, failing which the Regional Transport Authority has no jurisdiction to countersign?

anchor.surface_text: In the view of the High Court an application for renewal of the permit and an application for renewal of countersignature must be made within the period prescribed by S. 58 2 of the Act, and the appellant having failed to apply within that period,

issues.text: Whether the provisions relating to renewal contained in s.58 have application to the application for countersignature of an inter-regional permit?

anchor.surface_text: it was urged on behalf of the appellant that by s. 63 3 the provisions contained in Ch. IV relating to grant. revocation and suspension of permits are made applicable to grant of countersignatures of permits, and to the application for countersignature of an inter- regional permit the provisions relating to renewal contained in s. 58 have no application.

issues.text: Whether a permit granted under s.45 is an integrated permit in respect of a unitary route and wholly ineffective until countersigned by the authority in the other region?

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the respondent submitted that a permit granted by an Authority competent under s. 45 of the Act is an integrated permit in respect of a unitary route, and until the permit is countersigned by the Authority in the other region, it is wholly ineffective.

issues.text: Whether rule 63 framed under s.68 authorises the issuing Regional Transport Authority to renew countersignatures unless the other authority directs otherwise, and prevails over s.63?

anchor.surface_text: Rule 63, by cl. a , provided The authority by which a permit is renewed may, unless any authority by which the permit has been countersigned with effect not terminating before the date of expiry of the permit has by general or special order otherwise directed, likewise renew any countersignature of the permit by endorsement of the permit

issues.text: Whether a permit granted by one Regional Transport Authority is valid in its own region without countersignature by the other Regional Transport Authority under s.63?

anchor.surface_text: Under S. 63 a permit granted by the Regional Transport Authority of one region is not valid in any other region, unless the permit has been countersigned by the Regional Transport Authority of that other region.

issues.text: Whether one Regional Transport Authority is competent to grant countersignature overriding the refusal/discretion exercised by another Regional Transport Authority under rule 63?

anchor.surface_text: The Regional Transport Authority, Jabalpur renewed the permit for the Jabalpur region, but declined to countersign the permit in exercise of the power conferred by r. 63 framed under s. 68 of the Motor Vehicles Act in respect of the route within the Rewa region.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not necessary to express opinion on contentions of parties as case decided on interpretation of rules.

arguments.claim: Permit granted under s.45 is an integrated permit for unitary route and wholly ineffective until countersigned by authority in other region.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the respondent submitted that a permit granted by an Authority competent under s. 45 of the Act is an integrated permit in respect of a unitary route, and until the permit is countersigned by the Authority in the other region, it is wholly ineffective.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e Authority granting the permit has jurisdiction, and when it is companyntersigned by the Regional Transport Authority of the other region, the permit

arguments.court_reasoning: Unable to agree; clearest implication of s.63 is that inter-regional permit valid in granting region without countersignature.

arguments.claim: State Government had no power to frame rule 63.

anchor.surface_text: There is nosubstance in the contention raised by counsel for the appellant that the State Government had nopower to frame rule 63.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: frame rule 63. Power to frame rules for carrying into effect the provisions of Ch. IV is expressly granted to the State Government by s. 68, and the

arguments.court_reasoning: Power expressly granted by s.68(1) to make rules for Ch.IV; no implied limitations if for carrying into effect provisions.

arguments.claim: Rule 63 confers power on authority renewing permit (issuing RTA) to also renew countersignature unless countersigning authority directed otherwise by general or special order.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 63, by cl. a , provided The authority by which a permit is renewed may, unless any authority by which the permit has been countersigned with effect not terminating before the date of expiry of the permit has by general or special order otherwise directed, likewise renew any countersignature of the permit by endorsement of the permit

arguments.claim: Rule 63 prevails over s.63 as statute subject to 'except as may be otherwise prescribed'.

anchor.surface_text: The Legislature has by providing in the opening part of sub- s.  1  Except as may be otherwise prescribed made the pro- vision subject to the rules framed under s. 68, and a rule conferring authority to countersign the permit in so far as it relates to another region upon the Authority who issues the permit is made. Rule 63 must therefore prevail over the direction of the statute.

arguments.claim: RTA Jabalpur declined to countersign renewal under power in r.63 for Rewa region part; permit renewed only for Jabalpur region.

anchor.surface_text: The Regional Transport Authority, Jabalpur renewed the permit for the Jabalpur region, but declined to countersign the permit in exercise of the power conferred by r. 63 framed under s. 68 of the Motor Vehicles Act in respect of the route within the Rewa region.

arguments.claim: One RTA not competent to override discretion exercised by another RTA under statute; Rewa order invalid.

anchor.surface_text: In any event as one Regional Transport Authority is not competent to sit in judgment over the discretion exercised by any other Regional Transport Authority upon whom the power is conferred in regard to a particular matter under the statute, the order of the Regional Transport Authority, Rewa granting countersignature in the teeth of the earlier order of the Jabalpur Authority was invalid.

arguments.claim: Under s.63, permit granted by one RTA valid in its own region without countersignature by other RTA.

anchor.surface_text: Under S. 63 a permit granted by the Regional Transport Authority of one region is not valid in any other region, unless the permit has been countersigned by the Regional Transport Authority of that other region. The clearest implication of this provision is that even an inter-regional permit when granted is valid for the region over which the Authority granting the permit has jurisdiction,

holdings.text: The State Government had power to frame rule 63 under section 68 of the Motor Vehicles Act.

anchor.surface_text: There is nosubstance in the contention raised by counsel for the appellant that the State Government had nopower to frame rule 63. Power to frame rules for carrying into effect the provisions of Ch. IV is expressly granted to the State Government by s. 68, and the exercise of that power, if it be utilised for the purpose of carrying into effect the provisions of the Act, is number subject to any other implied limitations.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Power expressly granted by s.68(1) to make rules for Ch.IV; no implied limitations if for carrying into effect provisions.

holdings.text: Rule 63 confers power on the authority renewing the permit (issuing RTA) to renew countersignature unless the countersigning authority has directed otherwise by general or special order.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 63, by cl. a , provided The authority by which a permit is renewed may, unless any authority by which the permit has been countersigned with effect not terminating before the date of expiry of the permit has by general or special order otherwise directed, likewise renew any countersignature of the permit by endorsement of the permit

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual interpretation of r.63(a); issuing RTA competent to countersign unless directed otherwise.

holdings.text: Rule 63 prevails over section 63(1) because s.63(1) is subject to 'except as may be otherwise prescribed' making it subject to rules under s.68.

anchor.surface_text: The Legislature has by providing in the opening part of sub- s.  1  Except as may be otherwise prescribed made the pro- vision subject to the rules framed under s. 68, and a rule conferring authority to countersign the permit in so far as it relates to another region upon the Authority who issues the permit is made. Rule 63 must therefore prevail over the direction of the statute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language subordinates s.63 to rules; harmonious construction.

holdings.text: A permit granted by the Regional Transport Authority of one region is valid in that region without countersignature by the other region's RTA under s.63.

anchor.surface_text: Under S. 63 a permit granted by the Regional Transport Authority of one region is number valid in any other region, unless the permit has been countersigned by the Regional Transport Authority of that other region. The clearest implication of this provision is that even an inter-regional permit when granted is valid for the region over which the Authority granting the permit has jurisdiction,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clear textual implication of s.63: invalid only in other region, valid in granting region.

holdings.text: The Regional Transport Authority Jabalpur renewed the permit only for the Jabalpur region and declined to countersign for Rewa region under r.63.

anchor.surface_text: The Regional Transport Authority, Jabalpur renewed the permit for the Jabalpur region, but declined to countersign the permit in exercise of the power conferred by r. 63 framed under s. 68 of the Motor Vehicles Act in respect of the route within the Rewa region.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on recital in Rewa order, accepted by counsel; application of r.63.

holdings.text: One Regional Transport Authority is not competent to override or sit in judgment over the discretion exercised by another RTA under the statute.

anchor.surface_text: In any event as one Regional Transport Authority is number competent to sit in judgment over the discretion exercised by any other Regional Transport Authority upon whom the power is conferred in regard to a particular matter under the statue, the order of the Regional Transport Authority, Rewa granting countersignature in the teeth of the earlier order of the Jabalpur Authority was invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No RTA can review another's statutory discretion; jurisdictional limits.

holdings.text: The order of RTA Rewa granting countersignature is invalid.

anchor.surface_text: In any event as one Regional Transport Authority is number competent to sit in judgment over the discretion exercised by any other Regional Transport Authority upon whom the power is conferred in regard to a particular matter under the statue, the order of the Regional Transport Authority, Rewa granting countersignature in the teeth of the earlier order of the Jabalpur Authority was invalid.

holdings.text: The Supreme Court confirms the High Court order quashing the Rewa countersignature order, but for different reasons.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore confirm the order of the High Court, but for different reasons.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreed on result (quashing), disagreed on reasoning (limitation vs. override).

holdings.text: The permit granted/renewed by RTA Jabalpur remains valid for the route between Jabalpur and the point of entry into Rewa region.

Section 63 MV Act states that provisions for grant etc. apply to countersignatures, directly addressing whether s.58 renewal provisions apply to countersignature applications for inter-regional permits, potentially involving interpretation of 'grant etc.' consistent with reading down principles where ambiguous language allows narrower constitutional reading.

The concept c6 defines the requirement under Section 58(2) MV Act for renewal applications to be made not less than 60 days before expiry, which directly addresses the issue i1 concerning whether such timing applies to countersignature renewals.

anchor.surface_text: The Legislature has by providing in the opening part of sub- s.  1  Except as may be otherwise prescribed made the pro- vision subject to the rules framed under s. 68, and a rule conferring authority to countersign the permit in so far as it relates to another region upon the Authority who issues the permit is made. Rule 63 must therefore prevail over the direction of the statute.

We therefore companyfirm the order of the High Court, but for different reasons. We deem it, however, necessary to make it clear that our order does number affect the validity of the permit -ranted by the Regional Transport Authority, Jabalpur, insofar as it relates to the route between Jabalpur and

anchor.surface_text: Under S. 63 a permit granted by the Regional Transport Authority of one region is number valid in any other region, unless the permit has been countersigned by the Regional Transport Authority of that other region. The clearest implication of this provision is that even an inter-regional permit when granted is valid for the region over which the Authority granting the permit has jurisdiction,

We therefore companyfirm the order of the High Court, but for different reasons. We deem it, however, necessary to make it clear that our order does number affect the validity of the permit -ranted by the Regional Transport Authority, Jabalpur, insofar as it relates to the route between Jabalpur and

We therefore companyfirm the order of the High Court, but for different reasons. anchor.surface_text: In any event as one Regional Transport Authority is number competent to sit in judgment over the discretion exercised by any other Regional Transport Authority upon whom the power is conferred in regard to a particular matter under the statue, the order of the Regional Transport Authority, Rewa granting countersignature in the teeth of the earlier order of the Jabalpur Authority was invalid.

We therefore companyfirm the order of the High Court, but for different reasons. We deem it, however, necessary to make it clear that our order does number affect the validity of the permit -ranted by the Regional Transport Authority, Jabalpur, insofar as it relates to the route between Jabalpur and
